pageTitle: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 780 Ti Video Card Review GTX 780 Ti GeForce GTX 780 Ti, Graphics Card, NVIDIA, Olin Coles, Review

textBeforeTable: The temperatures illustrated below are absolute maximum values, and do not represent real-world temperatures created by video games or graphics applications: Using a modified version of FurMark’s “Torture Test” to generate maximum thermal load, peak GPU temperature is recorded in high-power 3D mode. FurMark does two things extremely well: drives the thermal output of any graphics processor much higher than any video games realistically could, and it does so with consistency every time. Furmark works great for testing the stability of a GPU as the temperature rises to the highest possible output. This section reports our temperature results subjecting the video card to maximum load conditions. During each test a 20°C ambient room temperature is maintained from start to finish, as measured by digital temperature sensors located outside the computer system. GPU-Z is used to measure the temperature at idle as reported by the GPU, and also under load. GeForce GTX 780 Ti Temperatures These results position the GTX 780 Ti among the least power-hungry top-end video cards we’ve tested under load, but much more impressive is that it’s achieved by a flagship GTX-series product. If you’re familiar with electronics, it will come as no surprise that less power consumption equals less heat output as evidenced by our thermal results below… Measured at the lowest reading, GeForce GTX 780 Ti consumed a mere 12W at idle. NVIDIA’s average TDP is specified as 250W, however our real-world stress tests using 3D Mark Vantage caused this video
textAfterTable: As we’ve mentioned on the pages leading up to this section, NVIDIA’s Kepler architecture yields a much more efficient operating GPU compared to previous designs. This becomes evident by the low idle temperature, and translates into modest full-load temperatures. While NVIDIA’s reference design works exceptionally well at cooling the GK110 GPU on GeForce GTX 780 Ti, consumers should expect add-in card partners to advertise unnecessarily excessive over-cooled versions for an extra premium. 82°C after ten minutes at 100% load using Furmark’s Torture Test is nothing at all, and is nowhere close to this card’s 95°C thermal threshold (which the R9 290X could actually reach).
